title-group.article-title: Correlation of density and properties of particleboard from coffee waste with urea–formaldehyde and polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Packaging Technology, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand
2Materials Science Research Center, Chiang Mai University, Thailand

abstract.p: The effect of urea–formaldehyde adhesive and polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates adhesive on the manufacture of particleboard using coffee waste as a raw material was investigated. The coffee waste was blended with the urea–formaldehyde or polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates, then hot-pressed at 140°C at two pressure levels. The particleboards were tested to certify their density, moisture content, thickness swelling, water absorption, bending strength and modulus of elasticity. The density, moisture content and bending strength of the sample increased, but thickness swelling and water absorption decreased with increasing quantity of the urea–formaldehyde and polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates. The particleboard with urea–formaldehyde and polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates at the same quantity, the density, moisture content, thickness swelling, water absorption, bending strength and modulus of elasticity of polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates were better than urea–formaldehyde adhesive. At the same adhesive content, the urea–formaldehyde adhesive samples above 18% urea–formaldehyde content and all of the samples with PMDI adhesive met the Thai industrial standards.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the 1930s, particleboards were first made. The particleboard industry first developed out of the shortage of lumber and the need to dispose of large quantities of sawdust and agricultural waste material produced by other wood industries.1 Particleboards are currently manufactured from particles of wood or other lignocellulose material, formed and pressed together by the use of an organic binder together with one or more other binding agents, including heat, pressure and catalysts.2

Many studies have been done on the properties of particleboard. For example, Wu3 manufactured particleboard from hammer mille bagasse. A combination of two adhesive contents (5% and 8% polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanates (PMDI)) and two density (0.72 and 0.88 g/cm3) levels were used. Performance characteristics of the particleboard including modulus of elasticity (MOE) and modulus of rupture (MOR), internal bond (IB) strength, hardness, linear expansion (LE) and thickness swelling (TS) were evaluated. The author observed that an increase in resin content level reached higher strength and less TS in general. Nacar et al.4 studied some of the physical and mechanical properties of particleboard made from eucalyptus (Eucalyptus camaldulensis). Bending properties of the samples produced using two levels of adhesive content (7% and 8% urea–formaldehyde (UF)) and density was found to be statistically different from each other. They suggested that overall mechanical properties increased with increasing particleboard density, press time and adhesive content. Another researcher Nemli5 studied the effects of particle, moisture content, shelling ratio and the addition of wood dust on the mechanical properties (static bending, MOE and IB) and physical property (TS) of particleboard made from Alder (Alnus glutinosa subsp. Barbata). The addition of 10% wood dust to the particles decreased the TS, MOE and bending strength, while increasing internal bonding. Particleboards produced from particles with 1% moisture content had lower IB, MOE and bending strength and higher TS values than those produced from particles with 4% moisture content. Increasing the face: core ratio from 30:70% to 45:55% also improved the physical and mechanical properties of the particleboards. Furthermore, Pan et al.6 used a rice bran adhesive (RBA) to replace part of the PMDI adhesive in rice straw-based particleboard to evaluate the properties of particleboard by measuring mechanical and water absorption (WA) properties. They tested RBA to replace 10%, 20% and 30% of PMDI adhesive. The properties of the resulting mixed adhesive products were then evaluated and compared with particleboard bond with only PMDI. Up to 30% of the PMDI could be replaced with RBA to yield products with properties similar to those of PMDI bond particleboard.

From this, it can be seen that there are many factors which can affect the physical and mechanical properties of particleboard. Kelly7 proposed that the two most important factors controlling the average final density of a particleboard are the raw material density and the compaction of the mat in the hot press. Any change in one of these factors requires an alteration of the other if the average board density is to remain constant. Similarly, either of these factors can be changed to increase or decrease the average particleboard density. However, higher density panels produced by increasing the compaction level will not have properties equal to the same-density panel produced with higher density wood furnish. The bending strength depends on the density of the particleboard, particle configuration, adhesive type and level and pressing condition. The MOR and MOE increase with board density when all other factors (particle configuration and orientation, species, adhesive content, pressing conditions, etc.) are constant. The reviewed literature does not have any reported decrease in MOR and MOE when average board density increases. The effect of particle geometry on the resultant panel MOR values appears to be fairly well established. Particles of high length/thickness ratios, in which structural damage is minimal, normally produce particleboards with superior MOR values. The MOE is strongly dependent upon chip length. The particleboards produced from longer chip were found to have substantially higher effective MOE. Moreover, increasing the adhesive content increases the MOE in generalc.

Recent interest in environmentally friendly materials has led to the use of agricultural residues as raw material to produce particleboard from coconut chips,8 bagasse9 and waste tea leaves.10 Further, coffee husk and hulls can be used to produce a value-added product such as particleboard or building insulation.11 Solid waste from coffee brewing is a major contributor to the total worldwide waste since coffee is a popular beverage and people around the world drink coffee about 1000 million cups per day. Coffee is today grown in more than 60 tropical counties around the world and is a primary export of many developing countries. Coffee is one of the most valuable traded commodities and comprises about 1% of the overall value of world trade. The two most commonly grown varieties are the highly regarded Coffea arabica and Coffea canephora (Robusta).12 In 2009, the total world production of coffee was 7.4 million tons, valued at US$ 18.9 billion.13 In Thailand, the crop area of coffee is 57,098 ha and production is 51,508 tons. The Thai Government has encouraged planting to further decrease dependency on foreign imports.14 In order to reduce coffee waste, many studies have been carried out on the application of coffee. Coffee pulp represents a valuable source of energy and can be used for anaerobic biogas production.15,16 In addition, coffee wastes can be used to extract oils and convert to fuel17 and biodiesel.18 However, there is no researcher using coffee waste as raw material to manufacture panels such as particleboard.
The main ideas in this study was to produce particleboard from coffee waste and to study the effects of UF and PMDI content on the physical and mechanical properties of the resulting materials.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Coffee waste materials were obtained with Arabica and Robusta in a ratio 1:1 from the coffee shop at Science Building 2, Chiang Mai University, Muang, Chiang Mai, Thailand. UF adhesive was purchased from Toa-Dovechem Industries Co., Ltd., Thailand. PMDI adhesive was purchased from Hustsman Polyurethanes, Thailand.

sec.title: Raw material preparation
sec.p: The coffee waste was dried at 105°C for 6 h in a hot-air oven (Model: 1370FX-2E, Sheldon Manufacturing Inc., Cornelius, OR, USA). After drying, the moisture content of the coffee waste was about 8% then sieved with a 20-mesh size (Sieve Shakers, Octagon 200, Endicott Ltd., NY, USA). The moisture content of the coffee waste was determined for calculating the ratio between adhesive content and coffee waste.

sec.title: Board manufacture
sec.p: The coffee waste was weighed about 100 g. The UF adhesive was measured at 15, 20, 25 and 35 ml that were equal to 11, 14.5, 18 and 25%w/w coffee waste, respectively. The PMDI adhesive was measured at 32, 42, 52 and 72 ml that were equal to 11, 14.5, 18 and 25%w/w coffee waste, respectively. Next, the coffee waste was blended with UF or PDMI (11%, 14.5%, 18% and 25%) and the mixture was formed into a mat 160 × 160 mm in a 6-mm-thick stainless steel frame. The mat was pressed using hot compression (Carver, MA, USA) at 140°C with two pressure levels (44.48 and 66.72 kN for 7 and 8 min, respectively) and cooled to room temperature within 8 min.

Prior to property evaluation of the mechanical properties, the board samples were cut and then sanded to certify their density, moisture content, TS, WA, bending strength and MOE complied to Thai industrial standards (TIS).19 The samples were then conditioned in 65 ± 5% relative humidity at about 25 ± 2°C, until reaching constant mass except for density and moisture content.

sec.title: Effect of UF and PMDI on density of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p: In particleboard manufacturing, the UF content is usually set to be around 6–10%.4,20–22 However, when using coffee waste board blended with a standard amount of UF, the content did not consolidate because the coffee waste consisted of tiny particles. Therefore, to produce coffee waste board, higher UF content was required than for other materials. This is in-line with Bekalo and Reinhardt,11 who used 15% UF content to produce the particleboard from coffee husk and hulls.

The differences in density between the coffee boards are shown in Figure 1, where the density values increased with increasing quantity of the adhesive. As expected, increasing the solid content of the adhesive results in an increased density. According to Iskanderani,22 a second contribution to the density arises from the UF polymer. UF having a higher density than that of wood makes a measurable difference in the density. The higher the percentage of UF, the higher the density of the particleboard. The most important factors controlling the density of a particleboard are the raw material density, the adhesive density and the compaction of the mat in the heating press.7 In addition, the density of the PMDI-bonded board was found to be lower than UF-bonded board due to the lower specific gravity of PMDI adhesive. Effect of adhesive content on density of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Effect of UF and PMDI on moisture content of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p:
The effect of adhesive content on the moisture content of particleboard from coffee waste is shown in Figure 2. The moisture content of UF- and PMDI-bonded particleboards measured 2.52–4.37% and 2.35–3.22%, respectively. The higher UF content means more polarity to react with water. The higher moisture content for UF-bonded boards can be traced back to the hygroscopic behavior of the alkali in the UF adhesive. Thus, more water is adsorbed which is why the moisture content increased with increasing UF content. The moisture content values of PMDI-bonded board were lower than UF-bonded board. PMDI adhesive consist of oils, which is unlike UF adhesive, which is an alkali that can absorb more water. Figure 2.
Effect of adhesive content on moisture content of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Effect of UF and PMDI on WA of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p:
Figure 3(a) and (b) shows the variation of water absorption (WA) after 2 and 24 h water immersion of the particleboards. WA gradually decreased as the adhesive content increased from 11% to 25%. These results agree with many studies.22,23 The WA values in this study were relatively high owing to the porous character of the lower UF content board, which absorbed more water than the compressed higher UF content board (Figure 3(a) and (b)). All these properties were higher for 24 h of water immersion than water immersion for 2 h. When soaking time increased the WA value increased. This agrees with previous studies Akaranta24 and Viswanathan et al.25 Moreover, PMDI is a nonpolar adhesive which when added lead to a polarity decrease. Consequently, increasing the PMDI content decreased WA (Figure 3(a) and (b)). Figure 3.
Effect of adhesive content on water absorption after (a) 2-h and (b) 24-h water immersion of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Effect of UF and PMDI on TS of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p:
The TS values of particleboards with UF and PMDI are shown in Figure 4, respectively. The TS values are mainly affected by the adhesive content. The TS slightly decreased when the adhesive content was increased. Kelly7 observed that higher adhesive content has been consistently shown to improve thickness swell behavior of particleboard. This leads to a higher degree of cross-linking resulting in retarded water penetration. This is similar to Paul et al.26 who observed an improvement in dimensional stability of phenol-formaldehyde (PF)-, melamine-urea-phenol-formaldehyde MUPF- and PMDI-bonded oriented strand board (OSB) properties, including TS. The PF and MUPF-bonded panels showed higher TS compared to panels bonded with PMDI. The authors explain this by the alkali in the PF- and MUPF-resin of PF- and MUPF-bonded panels which can uptake the water to the panel as a hygroscopic behavior. The TS is mainly influenced by the type of adhesive. UF-bonded board shows higher TS compared to board bonded with PMDI. This can be explained by the slower water uptake of the PMDI-bonded board. Because PMDI adhesive consist of oils, PMDI-bonded board can absorb less water than UF-bonded board. Carll27 suggested oil tempering of is generally recognized to reduce WA and TS. Furthermore, some previous studies observed that use of an isocyanate adhesive could result in superior resistance to thickness swell.28,29 Figure 4.
Effect of adhesive content on thickness swelling of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Effect of UF and PMDI on MOR and MOE of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p:
The measured values of the MOR and MOE are shown in Figures 5 and 6. The MOR and MOE increased as the resin content increased. An increase of the adhesive content from 11% to 25% resulted in a substantial improvement of MOR and MOE for coffee waste boards. It can be seen that higher adhesive content levels resulted in improved mechanical properties.30 The MOR and MOE values obtained in this study are in general agreement with previous studies.11,20,31 The MOR and MOE of particleboard with PMDI (Figures 5 and 6, respectively) were superior to those bonded with UF. This is similar to Bekalo and Reinhardt,11 who successfully made particleboards from coffee husk and hulls. The differences in the mechanical properties indicate that the bonding mechanism with UF resin was less efficient than that achieved using PMDI resin. It is likely that this reflects on the differences in the chemistry of the two resins. Moreover, the MOR value of the particleboards increased with increasing board density, which is a similar trend to that observed for conventional particleboards.9,32 According to Malonney,33 the MOE and MOR are strongly influenced by the particleboard’s compaction amount, particle geometry, percentage of adhesives and density. Figure 5.
Effect of adhesive content on the modulus of rupture of particleboard from coffee waste. Figure 6.
Effect of adhesive content on modulus of elasticity of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Correlation of board density and physical properties of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p: WA gradually decreased as the adhesive content increased from 11% to 25%. These results agree with many studies.22,23 The WA values in this study were relatively high owing to the porous character of the lower UF content board, which absorbed more water than the compressed higher UF content board. All these properties were higher for 24 h of water immersion than water immersion for 2 h. When soaking time increased the WA value increased. This agrees with previous studies.24,25 Moreover, PMDI is a nonpolar adhesive which when added leads to a polarity decrease. Consequently, increasing the PMDI content decreased WA.

WA of particleboard from coffee waste decreased with increasing board density (Figures 7 and 8), which is similar to the results found by Xu et al.32 The WA results of the 24 h water immersion test were highly correlated with the board density.7 Water entry into the higher density boards occurred at a slower rate due to the decreased porosity and the increased wood material. The longer times for these relative humidities allowed the moisture to equalize much more uniformly through the board than was possible for the 24 h water immersion. The lower level of moisture absorbed by the higher density boards clearly shows this behavior. Figure 7.
Effect of board density on water absorption (WA) after 2-h water immersion of particleboard from coffee waste. Figure 8.
Effect of board density on water absorption (WA) after 24-h water immersion of particleboard from coffee waste.

The TS values are mainly affected by the adhesive content. The TS slightly decreased when the adhesive content was increased. Kelly7 observed that higher adhesive content has been consistently shown to improve thickness swell behavior of particleboard. This leads to a higher degree of cross-linking resulting in retarded water penetration. This is similar to Paul et al.26 who observed an improvement in dimensional stability of PF-, MUPF- and PMDI-bonded OSB properties, including TS. The PF- and MUPF-bonded panels showed higher TS compared to panels bonded with PMDI. The authors explain this by the alkali in the PF- and MUPF-resin of PF- and MUPF-bonded panels which can uptake the water to the panel as a hygroscopic behavior. The TS is mainly influenced by the type of adhesive. UF-bonded board shows higher TS compared to board bonded with PMDI. This can be explained by the slower water uptake of the PMDI-bonded board. Because PMDI adhesive consist of oils, PMDI-bonded board can absorb less water than UF-bonded board. Carll27 suggested oil tempering of is generally recognized to reduce WA and TS. Furthermore, some previous studies observed that use of an isocyanate adhesive could result in superior resistance to thickness swell.28,29 Figure 9 shows the effect of board density on the TS value of particleboard from coffee waste. The TS values decreased with increasing board densities. Kelly7 observed the effect of board density on the TS of particleboard is confounded with the spring-back behavior. Therefore, it is not remarkable that TS is normally reported to increase with increasing board density.34 Roffael and Rauch35 reported that the reduced porosity of the high-density boards, as compared to those of lower density, prevented rapid liquid water penetration. The diffusion path of water into the individual component particles was much longer and the subsequent rate of TS was reduced for the high-density material. Figure 9.
Effect of board density on thickness swelling of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Correlation of board density and mechanical properties of particleboard from coffee waste
sec.p: The MOR and MOE increased as the resin content increased. An increase of the adhesive content from 11% to 25% resulted in a substantial improvement of MOR and MOE for coffee waste boards. It can be seen that higher adhesive content levels resulted in improved mechanical properties.30 The MOR and MOE values obtained in this study are in general agreement with previous studies.11,20,31 The MOR and MOE of particleboard with PMDI were superior to those bonded with UF. This is similar to Bekalo and Reinhardt11 who successfully made particleboards from coffee husk and hulls. The differences in the mechanical properties indicate that the bonding mechanism with UF resin was less efficient than that achieved using PMDI resin. It is likely that this reflects on the differences in the chemistry of the two resins. Moreover, the MOR value of the particleboards increased with increasing board density, which is a similar trend to that observed for conventional particleboards.9,32 According to Malonney,33 the MOE and MOR are strongly influenced by the particleboard’s compaction amount, particle geometry, percentage of adhesives and density.

The effect of board density on the MOR and MOE of particleboard from coffee waste are shown in Figures 10 and 11. These figures show that the MOR and MOE values of particleboard from coffee waste increased almost linearly with increasing board density. This agrees with Widyorini et al.9 and Xu et al.32 All studies in which board density versus the MOR has been determined, report an increase in MOR with increasing board density. The surface density strongly affects MOR because bending stresses are higher at the surface. Consequently, MOR values are highly dependent upon the vertical density gradient; widely different values can be obtained for equal average board densities simply by changing the processing variables affecting the vertical density distribution.7 The literature contains many studies which report a direct relationship between board density and the effective MOE, all universally agree that an increase in density leads to an increased MOE. Figure 10.
Effect of density on modulus of rupture (MOR) of particleboard from coffee waste. Figure 11.
Effect of density on modulus of elasticity (MOE) of particleboard from coffee waste.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The results obtained in this study showed that coffee waste could be successfully used as a raw material to manufacture particleboards using UF and PMDI adhesive. Particleboards bonded with PMDI were superior to those bonded with UF. It is likely that this reflects on differences in the chemistry of the two resins. The density, moisture content, MOR and MOE of the sample increased and TS and WA decreased with increasing quantity of the adhesive. This shows that adhesive content is the main parameter which correlates with the physical and mechanical properties.
